page.title: 15CLUNTON
page.content: Clunton is the second largest village in the group of villages comprising Clunbury Civil Parish. It stands on both sides of the road running from Craven Arms to Clun. The river Clun bounds the village on the south side. It varies in depth from a few inches to several feet. There are trout, bullheads, minnows, crayfish and sticklebacks to be found in various stretches of the river. River birds are moorhens, kingfishers, dipper, heron, sandmartin, wagtails and mallard. A stream flows from above Gunridge to join the river at the Green. Water voles may be found in the stream. Heavy rain causes periodic flooding into one cottage during which time the owner has to move upstairs. The village has a cafe, caravan site and a packaging factory.
